# `r config$publication_sub_name` {.toc-ignore}

Published `r config$publication_date`

## Key findings (2023/24)

### NHS Low Income Scheme {.toc-ignore}

* The number of applications and issued certificates in 2023/24 was a slight decrease from 2022/23 but higher than the two years prior. There were 161,000 HC2 certificates, and 58,000 HC3 certificates, issued in 2023/24.

* Certificates were most commonly issued to people from the most deprived areas of the country and people from the younger (15-24) and older (65+) age groups.

### Maternity exemption certificates {.toc-ignore}

* The number of applications and certificates issued has risen over the past few years. There were 552,000 maternity exemption certificates issued in 2023/24.

* Almost two-thirds of medical exemption certificates were issued to women by 7 months before the expected due date. Less than 5% of certificates were issued after the expected due date.

* The number of maternity exemption certificates issued in the most deprived areas is a little lower than may be expected based on the distribution of live births.

### Medical exemption certificates {.toc-ignore}

* The number of applications and certificates issued has risen over the past few years following a drop during 2019/20 and 2021/22. There were 475,000 medical exemption certificates issued in 2023/24.

* The is a strong relationship with age, with the number of certificates issued rising as age rises.

### NHS Prescription Prepayment Certificate (PPC) {.toc-ignore}

* The number of PPC certificates purchased has increased in each of the past 5 years. The 12-month certificate is more popular than the 3-month certificate, with 2,070,000 12-month certificates issued in 2023/24 compared to 936,000 3-month certificates issued.

* The is a strong relationship with age, with the number of certificates issued rising as age rises.

* In 2023/24 the five London ICBs were the bottom five in terms of certificates issued per 10,000 population.

### NHS Hormone Replacement Therapy Prescription Prepayment Certificate (HRT PPC) {.toc-ignore}

* The HRT PPC was launched in April 2023, with 131,000 certificates being issued in the first month. This represents 23% of the 566,000 certificates issued in 2023/24.

* There is a strong relationship with deprivation, with the number of certificates issued rising as deprivation decreases. This relationship is similar to the pattern seen for patient's receiving prescribing of drugs licensed to treat menopause in the UK which are covered by the HRT PPC.

* The South West region has some of the largest rates of HRT PPCs issued. In 2023/24, 5 of the 7 ICBs in the South West region were in the top 10 for number of HRT PPCs issued per 10,000 population.

### NHS tax credit exemption certificates {.toc-ignore}

* The number of NHS tax credit exemption certificates has been declining for a number of years. As part of the Universal Credit rollout people are being migrated away from tax credits and onto new benefit schemes. In 2023/24 1,150,000 certificates were issued, compared to 3,740,000 in 2018/19.

* The age profile of recipients has changed over the past few years. In 2018/19, 55% of certificates were issued to people aged under 40 years old but in 2023/24 this has dropped to 30% of issued certificates.

## 1. Things you should know

### 1.1. Scope {.toc-ignore}

`r infoBox_border("Background",text = "The NHSBSA administer a range of services to help people with the health costs, include help with:

* NHS prescription costs
* NHS dental costs
* sight tests, glasses and contact lenses
* travel to receive NHS treatment
* NHS wigs and fabric supports

Full details of these schemes are available on the [NHS Help with Health Costs webpage](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-help-health-costs).

Six different certificate schemes are available, with different levels of help with health costs:

* [NHS Prescription Prepayment certificate     (PPC)](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/help-nhs-prescription-costs/nhs-prescription-prepayment-certificate-ppc)
* [NHS Tax credit exemption certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/exemption-certificates/nhs-tax-credit-exemption-certificates)
* [Medical exemption certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/check-if-you-have-nhs-exemption/medical-exemption-certificates)
* [Maternity exemption certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/check-if-you-have-nhs-exemption/maternity-exemption-certificates)
* [NHS Low Income Scheme (LIS)](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-low-income-scheme)
* [NHS Hormone Replacement Therapy Prescription Prepayment Certificate (HRT     PPC)](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/help-nhs-prescription-costs/nhs-hormone-replacement-therapy-prescription-prepayment-certificate-hrt-ppc)"
, width = "100%")`

These statistics provide estimates of volumes related to these certificate schemes. Data covers the financial years 2018/2019 to 2023/24, where the financial year runs from April 1 to March 31.

These statistics are based on information from applications and data captured during certificate processing activities. Therefore, where information has not been supplied or captured accurately, this may impact the quality of the statistics.

Figures has been reported split by individual help with health cost service. Although an individual could use multiple services, data governance rules prevent data from being linked across different service areas. 

Some of the help with health cost services covered in this publication are provided only for residents in England while some services are also provided for other countries in the United Kingdom. Within this summary report figures will represent all activity, with additional breakdowns by country available in the supporting datasets.

## 2. Results and commentary

### 2.1 NHS Low Income Scheme

`r infoBox_border("",text = "The NHS Low Income Scheme (LIS) provides income related help. Support is available for people who do not receive help with health costs via an existing exemption. This is a means tested benefit, but also considers council tax and housing costs.

NHS Low Income Scheme exemption provides help with:

* NHS prescriptions
* NHS dental treatment
* sight tests, glasses and contact lenses
* travel to receive NHS treatment
* NHS wigs and fabric supports

The amount of support provided is based on weekly income, necessary outgoings, plus any savings or investments. Issued certificates will also cover the applicant's partner and dependent children under 20 years old."
, width = "100%")`

#### Figure X: Number of applications received 2018/19 to 2023/24 {.toc-ignore}

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}
::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>There were 374,000 applications received in 2023/24</b>", width = "100%")`
:::

::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>Applications decreased 4% from 2022/23</b>", width = "100%")`
:::

```{r lis_application_chart}
lis_application_objs$chart
get_download_button(title = "Download chart data", data = lis_application_objs$chart_data, filename = "hwhc_figure_x")
```

Applicants will either complete a paper HC1 form or apply via the [online application for LIS](https://apply-for-help-with-nhs-costs.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/apply-online).

Applications will include new applicants and existing certificate holders reapplying. The number of applications will also include incomplete applications.

Applications to the NHS Low Income Scheme decreased slightly in 2023/24, with 374,000 applications compared to 388,000 applications in 2022/23. Despite this decrease, the number of applications received still higher than previous years.

Applications to the NHS Low Income Scheme are assessed to determine if the applicant qualifies for any support.

#### Figure X: Number of outcome decisions by support type 2018/19 to 2023/24 {.toc-ignore}

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}
::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>almost two-thirds of the 261,000 decisions issued in 2023/24 provided full help with health costs</b>", width = "100%")`
:::

::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>16% of decisions issued in 2023/24 resulted in no support to the applicant</b>", width = "100%")`
:::
:::

```{r lis_issued_chart}
lis_issued_objs$chart
get_download_button(title = "Download chart data", data = lis_issued_objs$chart_data, filename = "hwhc_figure_x")
```

Two levels of support are available from the NHS Low Income Scheme. Depending on the outcome of the assessment, applicants could receive:

* an [HC2 certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-low-income-scheme/hc2-certificates-full-help-health-costs) for full help with health costs, including free NHS prescriptions.
* an [HC3 certificate](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/nhs-low-income-scheme/hc3-certificates-limited-help-health-costs) for limited help with health costs. A HC3 certificate will show how much the holder has to pay towards health costs.

In some cases the outcome of the application assessment will not result in a HC2 or HC3 certificate. This includes people with existing means tested benefits that include health cost exemption. Also, applicants may not receive a certificate based on the financial assessment outcome. 

There were 261,000 decisions issued in 2023/24. This included 161,000 HC2 certificates and 58,000 HC3 certificates. Compared to 2022/23 there has been a slight decrease in the number of certificates issued.

The proportion of outcome decisions that do not include a HC2 or HC3 certificate has risen from 11% in 2018/19 to 16% in 2023/24.

An outcome decision is only issued to the applicant following the completion of the assessment. Therefore these figures will not include any applications that are ongoing or were abandoned before completion. 

#### Figure X: Estimated number of active NHS Low Income Scheme certificates 2019/20 to 2023/24 {.toc-ignore}

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}
::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>There were 492,000 active NHS Low Income Scheme certificates in 2023/24</b>", width = "100%")`
:::

::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>There were more active certificates in 2023/24 than 2022/23. This is despite a drop in the number of certificates issued.</b>", width = "100%")`
:::
:::

```{r lis_active_chart}
lis_active_objs$chart
get_download_button(title = "Download chart data", data = lis_active_objs$chart_data, filename = "hwhc_figure_x")
```

Active certificates measures the number of certificates valid in the specified financial year. Some NHS Low Income Scheme certificates can be valid up to 5 years. Therefore, the number of active certificates are higher than the certificates issued. 

When certificates expire a certificate holder could reapply, and may then end up with two (or more) active certificates within a single financial year.

The number of active certificates is only available from 2019/20 due to retention schedules for certificates prior to this period. It should be noted that active certificates are based solely on the start and expiration date of the issued certificates. This does not consider if the certificate holder was using the certificate or not.

Trends in active certificates are generally in line with certificates issued. In 2023/24 there were 355,000 HC2 certificates active and 137,000 active HC3 certificates.

#### Figure X: Number of NHS Low Income Scheme certificates issued, split by certificate type and duration (2023/24) {.toc-ignore}

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}
::: col-md-6

:::

::: col-md-6

```{r lis_duration_chart}
lis_duration_objs$chart
get_download_button(title = "Download chart data", data = lis_duration_objs$chart_data, filename = "hwhc_figure_x")
```

The duration of NHS Low Income Scheme certificates can vary from a little as a day to a maximum length of 5 years. 

The circumstances of the applicant will determine the duration of the certificate. This will reflect the chances of circumstances changing, with some common scenarios:

* Pensioners receiving full help may receive a 5 year certificate.
* Non final-year students may receive a 12 month certificate.
* Applicants in receipt of non-means tested benefit may receive a 12 month certificate.
* Applicants earning a wage may receive a 6 month certificate.
* Students nearing the end of their course may receive a short term certificate until the end of their course.

Almost 48,000 HC3 certificates, issued in 2023/24, were valid for a period of 12 months. This represents over 83% of all HC3 certificates issued in 2023/24. HC2 certificates show more variation in length than HC3 certificates. In 2023/24 43,000 HC2 certificates were valid for 6 months and 92,000 were valid for 12 months.

#### Figure X: Number of NHS Low Income Scheme certificates issued, split by certificate type and applicant age band (2023/24) {.toc-ignore}

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}
::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>Over half of the certificates issued in 2023/24 were to people aged under 25 or 65 and over</b>", width = "100%")`
:::

::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>In 2023/24 more certificates were issued to applicants aged 65 and over than any other age group</b>", width = "100%")`

```{r lis_age_chart}
lis_age_objs$chart
get_download_button(title = "Download chart data", data = lis_age_objs$chart_data, filename = "hwhc_figure_x")
```

NHS Low Income Scheme certificates cover the applicant, partners and any dependent children. Age information is only captured for the lead applicant though. 

Pensioners are more likely than other age groups to receive a long term certificate. This will impact the age distribution of certificates issued in a year as pensioners may only have to apply once every 5 years.

The younger and older age groups receive more certificates than other ages. Almost 52,000 certificates went to people aged 65 and over in 2023/24. A further 45,000 went to applicants 20-24 and 29,000 to applicants aged 19 and under. For HC3 certificates in particular this is stronger relationship with age with only 24% of certificates issued to people aged 25 to 64.

For outcome decisions where no certificate was issued there is less variation by age and more activity for people in the 30 to 54 age group. In 2023/24, over a quarter of the decisions issued to people aged 30 to 54 had no certificate issued.

#### Figure X: Number of NHS Low Income Scheme certificates issued, split by certificate type and IMD quintile (2023/24) {.toc-ignore}

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}

`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>In 2023/24 60,000 certificates went to people in the most deprived areas</b>", width = "100%")`
:::

```{r lis_imd_chart}
lis_imd_objs$chart
get_download_button(title = "Download chart data", data = lis_imd_objs$chart_data, filename = "hwhc_figure_x")
```

The English Indices of Deprivation provide a measure of deprivation. In this report deprivation reflects the applicant's registered address. [Section 3.3 of this summary](#about_imd) contains more information on this measure. These indices of deprivation are specific to England and therefore can only be applied to certificates that can be assigned to an English postcode.

Certificates were issued in the most deprived areas more than three times more often than the least deprived areas. 

The distribution of outcome decision is similar within each IMD quintile. This suggests that deprivation profile alone is not a strong indicator of whether or not an application will result in a HC2, HC3 or no certificate being issued. However, it should be noted that this will not include applications that were abandoned before being completed.

Despite being means-tested, certificates are still issued to applicants from less deprived areas. In 2023/24, over 13,000 HC2 certificates and over 5,000 HC3 certificates went to the least deprived areas.

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}

Population estimates use figures published by [Office for National Statistics for ICB population](https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/clinicalcommissioninggroupmidyearpopulationestimates). These figures are mid-year estimates with 2022 population estimates used for this report. These are the latest available population statistics at the time of publication. To align with the people who may benefit from the NHS Low Income Scheme, population figures are based on people aged 16 and over.

The map and chart are based on the total number of HC2 and HC3 certificates issued in 2023/24. This does not include any application outcomes where a HC2 or HC3 was not issued. Figures for individual application outcome types are included in the accompanying data.

North West London ICB had the highest estimated number of certificates issued per 10,000 population. In 2023/24, an estimated 79 certificates were issued per 10,000 population in this ICB. The top three ICBs in terms of certificates issued per 10,000 population were all from north London.

Surrey Heartlands ICB had the lowest estimated number of certificates issued per 10,000 population in 2023/24. This ICB had an estimated 25 certificates per 10,000 population.

### 2.2 Maternity exemption certificate

`r infoBox_border("",text = "Maternity exemption certifications exempt the holders from NHS prescription charges. It can also be used as as proof of entitlement to free NHS dental treatment.

Maternity exemption certificates are available to anybody who is currently pregnant, or has given birth in the last 12 months. The certificate is valid until 12 months after the birth of the baby.

Applications are submitted via a midwife, doctor or health visitor who confirms eligibility. Both paper and digital applications are available."
, width = "100%")`

#### Figure X: Number of applications received 2018/19 to 2023/24 {.toc-ignore}

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}
::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>There were 555,000 applications received in 2023/24</b>", width = "100%")`
:::

::: col-md-6
`r infoBox_no_border("", text = "<b>Applications increased 11% from 2022/23</b>", width = "100%")`
:::
:::

```{r matex_application_chart}
mat_application_objs$chart
get_download_button(title = "Download chart data", data = mat_application_objs$chart_data, filename = "hwhc_figure_x")
```

Applications for maternity exemption certificates dipped in 2020/2021 but has increased in each of the following years. In 2023/24, the increase in applications of 11% is the largest in recent years.

In 2023/24 there were 555,000 applications received, up from 499,000 in 2022/23.

Applications are submitted via a healthcare professional, who confirms eligibility. Therefore, only a small proportion of applications would not end with a certificate being issued. Certificates may not be issued if essential details cannot be confirmed by the applicant or other issues cannot be resolved. Due to the time taken to resolve an application, some certificates may be issued in a later time period to when the application was submitted.

#### Figure X: Number of certificates issued 2018/19 to 2023/24 {.toc-ignore}

::: {.row style="display: flex; padding-bottom: 15px;"}

The number of issued maternity exemption certificates dipped in 2020/2021 but has increased in each of the following years. In 2023/24, the increase in certificates issued of 12% is the largest in recent years.

In 2023/24 there were 551,000 maternity exemption certificates issued, up from 494,000 in 2022/23.

Maternity exemption certificates are valid from when a pregnancy is confirmed up to one year following birth. Therefore, some certificates may be valid across multiple financial years.

It should be noted that active certificates are based solely on the start and expiration date of the issued certificates. This does not consider if the certificate holder was using the certificate or not.

There have been over 1,100,000 maternity certificates active in each of the past five financial years. The 1,260,000 certificates active in 2023/24 is a 4% increase on the 1,210,000 certificates active in 2022/23.

Some certificates may be active in multiple financial years, and the number of years a certificate will cover depends on how early on during pregnancy the certificate is issued.

Maternity exemption certificates can be issued from the date the pregnancy is confirmed up to one year after the birth. Applications are submitted by a healthcare professional on the applicants behalf. Any delays in this process will impact the length of support available with some women not receiving a certificate until later in the pregnancy or until after the birth.

Over 60% of certificates issued in 2023/24 had been issued 7 months prior to the expected delivery date. This period would align with the stage in pregnancy that women start to interact with NHS maternity services. 

In almost 95% of cases, the certificate had been issued by the expected due date. Although only a small proportion of certificates were issued after the due date, this still represents 29,500 certificates where the mother did not have the maternity exemption certificate until after giving birth.

### 2.3 Medical exemption certificate

`r infoBox_border("",text = "Medical exemption certifications exempt the holders from NHS prescription charges only. Patients with any of the qualifying conditions can apply for a certificate. But it is the certificate that provides exemption - not the condition.

Patients can apply for a medical exemption certificate if they have either:

* a permanent fistula (for example, caecostomy, colostomy, laryngostomy or ileostomy) which needs continuous surgical dressing or an appliance
* a form of hypoadrenalism (for example, Addisonâ€™s Disease) for which specific substitution therapy is essential
* diabetes insipidus and other forms of hypopituitarism
* diabetes mellitus, except where treatment is by diet alone
* hypoparathyroidism
* myasthenia gravis
* myxoedema (hypothyroidism which needs thyroid hormone replacement)
* epilepsy which needs continuous anticonvulsive therapy
* a continuing physical disability which means you cannot go out without the help of another person
* cancer and are undergoing treatment for either:
  * cancer
  * the effects of cancer
  * the effects of cancer treatment

Medical exemption certificates are usually valid for 5 years. A GP or doctor can provide the application form to qualifying patients."
, width = "100%")`

### 2.4 NHS Prescription Prepayment Certificate (PPC)

`r infoBox_border("",text = "A PPC can help provide savings for people who pay for NHS Prescriptions. The certificate covers all a patient's NHS prescription charges for a set price. Patients will save money if they need 4 or more items in 3 months or 12 or more items in 12 months.

PPCs can be purchased in-person at some pharmacies or direct via the [PPC webpage](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/help-nhs-prescription-costs/nhs-prescription-prepayment-certificate-ppc). Applicants can choose between a 3-month and 12-month certificate.

Patients receiving prescriptions for hormone replacement therapy (HRT) may benefit more from the Hormone Replacement Therapy Prescription Prepayment Certificate (HRT PPC)."
, width = "100%")`

Applications for 12-month PPCs have shown a consistent year-on-year increase. In 2023/24 there were 2,160,000 applications received, up from 2,060,000 in 2022/23 which is a 5% increase. The number of issued Tax Credit Exemption Certificates has been dropping year on year from 3,740,000 in 2018/19 to 1,150,000 in 2023/24. This strong decline may be linked to the Universal Credit rollout as people are migrated to new benefit schemes. The number of certificates issued each year has declined by between 22% and 26% since 2019/2020.

Over three quarters of all certificates were issued to people aged between 35 and 54.

The English Indices of Deprivation provide a measure of deprivation. In this report deprivation reflects the applicant's registered address. [Section 3.3 of this summary](#about_imd) contains more information on this measure. These indices of deprivation are specific to England and therefore can only be applied to certificates that can be assigned to an English postcode.

There is a strong relationship between deprivation and number of NHS tax credit exemption certificates issued. This is to be expected as this is a means-tested benefit. In 2023/24, there were 394,000 certificates issued in the most deprived areas. In the least deprived areas only 67,700 certificates were issued in 2023/24.

Population estimates use figures published by [Office for National Statistics for ICB population](https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/clinicalcommissioninggroupmidyearpopulationestimates). These figures are mid-year estimates with 2022 population estimates used for this report. This is the latest available population statistics at the time of publication. To align with NHS tax credit exemption certificates, population figures are based on the population aged 16 and over.

There are a small number of ICBs where the number of certificates per 10,000 population is much higher than the rest of the country.

In 2023/24, North East London ICB had 510 certificates issued per 10,000 population. This was closely followed by 507 certificates per 10,000 population in Birmingham and Solihull ICB. Numbers then drop to 386 certificates per 10,000 population in North Central London ICB.

In 2023/24, Bath and North East Somerset, Swindon and Wiltshire ICB had the lowest rate, with only 85 certificates issued per 10,000 population.

## 3 About these statistics

### 3.1 Statistical Disclosure Control (SDC) {.toc-ignore}

Statistical disclosure control has been applied to these statistics. Volume figures have been redacted in the supporting summary tables if they relate to fewer than 5 items. Further information about our statistical disclosure control protocol [can be found on our website](https://www.nhsbsa.nhs.uk/policies-and-procedures).

### 3.2. Rounding {.toc-ignore}

The high-level figures in this statistical summary have been rounded where appropriate for clarity. In most cases rounding has been to two significant figures in the key findings and information boxes and three significant figures in the main text. This is to make this narrative as accessible as possible to all readers. The summary tables released with this publication allow users to investigate this data at lower levels of granularity. Figures in the supplementary tables have not been rounded.

### 3.3. Index of deprivation {#about_imd .toc-ignore}

The [English Indices of Deprivation 2019](https://www.gov.uk/government/statistics/english-indices-of-deprivation-2019) have been used to provide a measure of deprivation. The English Indices of Deprivation are an official national measure of deprivation that follows an established methodological framework to capture a wide range of individuals' living conditions.

The reported IMD quintile, where 1 is the most deprived and 5 the least deprived, is derived from the postcode currently held for an applicant. There are a small number of records each year that we have reported as having an unknown IMD quintile. These are applicants with no fixed abode or with british forces addresses, or where we have been unable to match the applicant postcode to an English postcode in the [XXX citation needed](https://geoportal.statistics.gov.uk/datasets/national-statistics-postcode-lookup-may-2022/about).

IMD quintiles are calculated by ranking census lower-layer super output areas (LSOAs) from most deprived to least deprived and dividing them into equal groups. These range from the most deprived 20% (quintile 1) of small areas nationally to the least deprived 20% (quintile 5) of small areas nationally.
